metadata.titleEn: Long time series data set of north temperate lake ice cover occurrence values (1985-2020)
metadata.description: The data set mainly includes the ice observation frequency (ICO) of north temperate lakes in four periods from 1985 to 2020, as well as the location, area and elevation of the lakes. Among them, the four time periods are 1985-1998 (P1), 1999-2006 (P2), 2007-2014 (P3) and 2015-2020 (P4) respectively, in order to improve the "valid observation" times in the calculation period and improve the accuracy. The ICO of the four periods is calculated by the ratio of "icing" times and "valid observation" times counted by all Landsat images in each period. Other lake information corresponds to the HydroLAKEs data set through the "hylak_id" column in the table. In addition, the data only retains about 30000 lakes with an area of more than 1 square kilometer, which are valid for P1-P4 observation. The data set can reflect the response of Lake icing to climate change in recent decades.
metadata.instructions: The data is stored in tabular form, and each row is the calculation result of a lake. The lake information corresponds to the hydrolakes dataset through the "hylak_id" column in the table. "Ico_p1 (%)"," ico_p2 (%)", "ico_p3 (%)" and "ico_p4 (%)" are the ICO results of four periods.

background: Half of the world's lakes (approximately 50 million) periodically freeze. The phenology of lake ice (i.e., freeze/thaw dates and duration) not only influences physical conditions (such as heat storage, temperature, mixing) of underlying ecosystems, but also provides important opportunities for transportation, recreation, and fishing for hundreds of millions of people worldwide. Recently, widespread reductions in lake ice have been detected at both regional and global scales due to recent climate warming, and this problem is projected to become more severe in the future due to ongoing warming trends and escalating climate extremes. Observations from both field surveys and satellite remote sensing have been widely used to identify historical trends in lake ice cover. Unfortunately, even with the well-maintained in situ data set from the National Snow and Ice Data Center (NSIDC), field records are available for only 631 lakes, and only ∼40 lakes have four decades of continuous records. Furthermore, the in situ lake ice records from NSIDC were spatially biased: few records were collected in Asian lakes or lakes located south of 40°N in the other continents. Although satellite remote sensing offers large-scale and frequent observations, the currently available applications are restricted to individual large lakes or lake districts.
research objective: However, spatially detailed quantification of the changes in lake ice at the global scale is not available. Here, we map ice cover in >33,000 lakes throughout the North Temperate Zone (23.5°–66.5°N) using 0.55 million Landsat images from 1985 to 2020. The high-resolution mapping of lake ice here provides essential baseline information which can be used to elucidate ice loss-induced environmental and societal impacts.
challenges: However, such efforts are challenging by using Landsat observations alone, where the ice cover conditions may change considerably between subsequent observations (16 days apart), not to mention the potential contamination from cloud coverage. However, the spatial resolution of ERA5-Land data sets is 0.1°, with a native resolution of 9 km. As such, the area of a cell grid size is ∼81 km², which is larger than most examined lakes. Owing to the apparent temperature disparities between water and adjacent land, the extracted gridded temperature may not accurately represent the lake temperature.
methods: We mapped lake ice cover over the entire North Temperate Zone using 30-m resolution Landsat satellite observations from 1985 to 2020. We determined lake ice extent for each Landsat image using the Fmask algorithm, which classifies snow/ice pixels using several thresholds (Normalized Difference Snow Index >0.15, Brightness Temperature <0.38, NIR band reflectance <0.11, and green band reflectance >0.1). To estimate the ICO of a lake within a given period, we used the following procedure. First, we counted (a) the number of times when a pixel was labeled snow/ice (Nice) and (b) the number of valid Landsat observations (Nvo) (pixel was not labeled as clouds or cloud shadows) in the first quarter of all years within the period. Second, we normalized Nice against Nvo to calculate the ICO at the pixel level. Pixels with limited valid observations (Nvo <10) were removed from further analysis to avoid meaningless statistics. Third, we estimated the mean value of all pixel-level ICO values within a predefined lake area, representing the ICO of this lake within this period. Validations with in situ records from various lakes distributed globally demonstrated the high reliability of using the Fmask algorithm to classify the status of lake ice from individual images and for ICO calculations at different periods. We estimated the absolute differences in mean temperature between different periods and examined the spatial consistencies of the ICO changes and temperature variability. To explore the impacts of temperature on individual lakes, we performed logistic regression between ICO values of the examined lakes and the corresponding mean temperature.
dataset: Using 0.55 million Landsat satellite images from 1985 to 2020, we provide the first long-term wall-to-wall mapping of lake ice cover over the entire Northern Temperate Zone, comprising >33,000 lakes representing 48% of the global lake area in total.
findings: Over this period, we found a remarkable reduction in median ice cover occurrence (ICO) (61% to 43%), which was strongly related to warming terrestrial mean surface temperatures (R2 = 0.94, p <0.05). Lakes in Europe showed the most pronounced ice loss (median ICO decreased from 50% to 24%), and extensive lake ice losses were also detected in the northern US, and central and eastern Asia. An overall increase in ice cover was identified from P2 (1999–2006) to P3 (2007–2014) due to regional decreased temperatures associated with the “global warming hiatus.”

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced when using satellite data to quantify changes in lake ice cover on a global scale?
Example.Answer: A challenge faced when using satellite data, such as Landsat observations, is the potential for ice cover conditions to change significantly between the 16-day intervals of subsequent observations, as well as the issue of cloud coverage contamination. Additionally, the spatial resolution of auxiliary datasets like ERA5-Land may not accurately represent the temperature of most examined lakes due to the scale difference.

Example.Question: Can you give an example of a dataset used to evaluate the response of lake ice cover to climate variability?
Example.Answer: An example of a dataset used for evaluating lake ice cover response to climate variability involves over 0.55 million Landsat satellite images from 1985 to 2020, which provided long-term mapping of lake ice cover over more than 33,000 lakes in the Northern Temperate Zone. This dataset captures changes in ice cover occurrence and its relationship with terrestrial mean surface temperature changes.

Definition.Question: What does 'ICO' mean in the context of lake ice cover datasets?
Definition.Answer: In the context of lake ice cover datasets, 'ICO' refers to the Ice Cover Occurrence, which is calculated as the ratio of the number of times a pixel was labeled as snow/ice to the number of valid Landsat observations in a given period. It represents the extent of ice cover for a lake during that period.

Definition.Question: What does the 'Fmask algorithm' refer to in satellite imagery analysis?
Definition.Answer: The 'Fmask algorithm' in satellite imagery analysis refers to a method used for classifying snow/ice pixels. It applies several thresholds such as the Normalized Difference Snow Index, Brightness Temperature, NIR band reflectance, and green band reflectance to differentiate between snow/ice and other surface types in Landsat images.

Definition.Question: What is meant by a 'global warming hiatus' in climate studies?
Definition.Answer: In climate studies, a 'global warming hiatus' refers to a period where there is a temporary slowdown or pause in the increase of global surface temperatures, despite ongoing climate change trends. This can lead to regional temperature decreases impacting phenomena such as lake ice cover.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in application and limitations between the Fmask algorithm used for classifying lake ice conditions and the use of gridded temperature data from ERA5-Land in lake ice studies?
Comparison.Answer: The Fmask algorithm classifies snow/ice pixels based on specific reflectance thresholds and offers high-resolution (30 m) mapping of lake ice, providing detailed local data but is limited by cloud cover and the temporal resolution of Landsat images. In contrast, ERA5-Land provides broader spatial coverage with gridded temperature data at a lower spatial resolution (∼81 km²), which might not accurately capture lake-specific temperatures due to temperature disparities between water and land.

Comparison.Question: How does the ICO calculation method using Landsat images compare to traditional field-based methods in terms of data availability and accuracy for assessing climate change impacts on lake ice cover?
Comparison.Answer: The ICO calculation using Landsat images offers a long-term, large-scale dataset with >0.55 million images, enabling detailed analysis of climate change impacts on over 33,000 lakes, which is not feasible with traditional field-based methods due to limited data availability. However, field-based methods may provide more accurate and direct measurements of lake ice conditions, while satellite-based methods rely on indirect indicators and are subject to limitations like cloud interference and temporal gaps.

Interpretation.Question: What challenges arise in using satellite remote sensing for collecting data on lake ice cover and how might these be overcome?
Interpretation.Answer: Challenges include potential contamination from cloud coverage and the changeability of ice cover conditions between the 16-day intervals of Landsat observations. Overcoming these challenges involves using algorithms like Fmask to classify snow/ice pixels and ensuring a sufficient number of valid observations to avoid meaningless statistics.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes challenges in accurately mapping lake ice cover using satellite remote sensing techniques?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Challenges arise from the interval between Landsat observations, which are 16 days apart, potentially missing changes in ice cover. Additionally, cloud coverage can contaminate observations, making it difficult to obtain accurate data. The spatial resolution of temperature datasets like ERA5-Land may not accurately represent conditions over smaller lakes due to temperature disparities between water and adjacent land.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the reasons behind the spatial bias in in situ lake ice records, and how does satellite remote sensing address this issue?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Spatial bias in in situ lake ice records is due to limited field data, with few records for Asian lakes or those south of 40°N. Satellite remote sensing offers broader coverage and frequent observations, allowing for the mapping of ice cover changes over a larger number of lakes, such as the >33,000 lakes in the North Temperate Zone, thus providing a more comprehensive dataset.

Causal Consequence.Question: How does relying solely on Landsat satellite observations influence the accuracy and temporal resolution of lake ice cover datasets in the Northern Temperate Zone?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Relying solely on Landsat satellite observations presents challenges, such as changes in ice cover conditions between the 16-day intervals of observations and potential contamination from cloud coverage. These challenges can affect the temporal resolution and accuracy of the dataset, making it difficult to capture precise changes in lake ice cover.

Causal Consequence.Question: What is the impact of using a high volume of Landsat images (0.55 million) on the comprehensiveness of ice cover mapping for lakes in the Northern Temperate Zone?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Utilizing a high volume of Landsat images allows for the first long-term wall-to-wall mapping of lake ice cover in the Northern Temperate Zone, covering over 33,000 lakes. This comprehensive dataset represents 48% of the global lake area, providing essential baseline information to understand environmental and societal impacts of ice loss.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the overarching aim of developing a long-term dataset mapping lake ice cover using high-resolution satellite imagery?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goal is to provide essential baseline information that can elucidate ice loss-induced environmental and societal impacts, by mapping ice cover in over 33,000 lakes throughout the North Temperate Zone using 0.55 million Landsat images from 1985 to 2020.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to address the spatial biases found in in situ data collection when studying lake ice cover?
Goal Orientation.Answer: It is crucial because the existing in situ lake ice records are spatially biased, with few records from Asian lakes or lakes south of 40°N, which limits understanding of global lake ice trends and responses to climate change.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary goal of using the Fmask algorithm in the context of lake ice cover detection?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary aim is to reliably classify snow/ice pixels in Landsat images to estimate ice cover occurrence (ICO) for lakes, thereby overcoming challenges associated with temporal gaps and cloud cover in satellite observations.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedural steps are involved in determining the ice cover occurrence (ICO) for lakes using satellite imagery?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The procedure involves using Landsat satellite observations to map lake ice cover. The Fmask algorithm is applied to classify snow/ice pixels based on several thresholds, such as Normalized Difference Snow Index, Brightness Temperature, and reflectance values in the NIR and green bands. The number of times a pixel is labeled as snow/ice and the number of valid observations without clouds are counted within a defined period. The ICO is calculated by normalizing the snow/ice occurrences against the valid observations. Pixels with fewer than 10 valid observations are excluded to avoid skewed statistics. The mean ICO value for a predefined lake area is estimated for each period.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How are the challenges of cloud coverage and temporal gaps in satellite images addressed when mapping lake ice cover?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The challenges are addressed by using a high-resolution mapping technique with Landsat images, which are taken every 16 days. The Fmask algorithm helps classify the ice cover status by using a set of thresholds to ensure reliable pixel classification. Despite cloud coverage and temporal gaps, the procedure ensures enough valid observations are used for ICO estimation by removing pixels with less than 10 valid observations.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methodological approach is taken to validate the accuracy of lake ice classification from satellite imagery?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The methodological approach involves validating the satellite-based lake ice classifications using in situ records from various lakes globally. The Fmask algorithm's reliability is assessed by comparing its classifications with these ground-based observations, ensuring accurate representation of lake ice status across different periods. Logistic regression analysis is also performed to explore the relationship between ICO values and mean temperature changes, adding another layer of validation to the findings.

Enablement.Question: What advancements in satellite remote sensing have enabled the detailed mapping of lake ice cover over extensive geographic areas?
Enablement.Answer: The use of 0.55 million Landsat satellite images from 1985 to 2020 enabled the detailed mapping of lake ice cover over the entire Northern Temperate Zone, comprising over 33,000 lakes.

Enablement.Question: How do specific image classification algorithms enable the accurate determination of ice cover in large datasets?
Enablement.Answer: The Fmask algorithm was used to accurately classify snow/ice pixels in Landsat images by applying several thresholds, which helped determine lake ice extent effectively.

Enablement.Question: What data processing methods enable the normalization and analysis of ice cover occurrence across disparate time periods and lake locations?
Enablement.Answer: The process involved counting valid observations and snow/ice occurrences, normalizing these counts, and estimating mean values within predefined lake areas, which enabled analysis of ice cover occurrence across different periods.

Expectation.Question: Why might data collected through satellite observations be expected to encounter challenges in accurately representing lake ice cover?
Expectation.Answer: Data collection through satellite observations like Landsat may face challenges because ice cover conditions can change significantly between subsequent observations, which are 16 days apart. Additionally, cloud coverage can contaminate the data, and temperature data extracted from gridded sources may not accurately reflect lake temperature due to disparities between water and adjacent land temperatures.

Expectation.Question: Why would a dataset of lake ice cover potentially need to explore new approaches for resolving challenges related to spatial resolution and accuracy?
Expectation.Answer: New approaches may be needed because the spatial resolution of datasets like ERA5-Land is relatively coarse compared to most lakes, with a grid size larger than many lakes examined. This discrepancy can lead to inaccuracies in representing lake-specific conditions, emphasizing the need for methods that can better capture the unique environmental conditions of smaller lakes.

Judgmental.Question: What are the potential challenges in using Landsat satellite images for mapping lake ice cover, and how might these challenges impact data accuracy and reliability?
Judgmental.Answer: The use of Landsat satellite images for mapping lake ice cover presents challenges such as considerable changes in ice cover conditions between subsequent observations (16 days apart) and potential contamination from cloud coverage. These challenges might impact data accuracy and reliability by introducing gaps or errors in the observed ice cover data, which could affect the overall assessment of ice cover trends and their environmental implications.

Judgmental.Question: How could the methodologies for determining ice cover occurrence (ICO) be refined to improve accuracy and address potential limitations identified in current data collection techniques?
Judgmental.Answer: The methodologies for determining ice cover occurrence (ICO) could be refined by incorporating additional data sources, such as higher frequency satellite observations or more comprehensive in situ temperature records, to reduce the impact of observation gaps and cloud contamination. Additionally, improving the spatial resolution and accuracy of temperature data used in logistic regression models could enhance the understanding of temperature impacts on lake ice dynamics.

Judgmental.Question: What is the role of high-resolution mapping in understanding the societal and environmental impacts of lake ice loss, and how might this influence future research priorities or data collection strategies?
Judgmental.Answer: High-resolution mapping plays a crucial role in understanding the societal and environmental impacts of lake ice loss by providing essential baseline information on ice cover changes across a vast number of lakes. This detailed mapping can inform future research priorities by highlighting regions or lakes most vulnerable to climate change impacts, potentially guiding more targeted data collection strategies and policy interventions to address these emerging challenges.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about the impact of cloud coverage on the reliability of satellite-based lake ice data collection.
Assertion.Answer: Cloud coverage can significantly impact the reliability of satellite-based data collection because clouds can obscure the view of the lake surface in satellite images. In the research approach, the Fmask algorithm was employed to classify snow/ice pixels, and only valid Landsat observations (where pixels were not labeled as clouds or cloud shadows) were used to calculate the ice cover occurrence (ICO). This process helps mitigate the impact of cloud coverage, but it remains a challenge in ensuring consistent data quality.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how the changes in temperature are quantified in relation to changes in lake ice cover.
Assertion.Answer: Changes in temperature are quantified by estimating the absolute differences in mean temperature between different periods and examining the spatial consistencies of ICO changes alongside temperature variability. Logistic regression is performed between the ICO values of the examined lakes and the corresponding mean temperature to explore the impacts of temperature on individual lakes. This approach helps in understanding the strong relationship between warming terrestrial mean surface temperatures and reductions in median ice cover occurrence.

Request/Directive.Question: Please provide an analysis of the challenges faced in using satellite remote sensing for lake ice cover mapping, particularly focusing on the resolution and temporal frequency of observations.
Request/Directive.Answer: Challenges in using satellite remote sensing for lake ice cover mapping include the considerable changes in ice cover conditions between subsequent Landsat observations, which are 16 days apart, and potential contamination from cloud coverage. Additionally, the spatial resolution of some datasets, such as ERA5-Land with a cell grid size of approximately 81 km², is larger than most examined lakes, which may result in inaccurate representations of lake temperature due to temperature disparities between water and adjacent land.

Request/Directive.Question: Please describe a comprehensive research approach to assess the impacts of temperature variability on lake ice cover in the Northern Temperate Zone using remote sensing data.
Request/Directive.Answer: A comprehensive research approach to assess the impacts of temperature variability on lake ice cover involves mapping lake ice cover across the Northern Temperate Zone using Landsat satellite observations from 1985 to 2020. The Fmask algorithm is used to determine lake ice extent for each image. The procedure includes calculating the ICO by counting the number of snow/ice occurrences and valid Landsat observations, normalizing these values, and estimating the mean ICO within a predefined lake area. Researchers can then perform logistic regression between ICO values and mean temperature to explore temperature impacts on individual lakes.
